item.title: Hala add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "I had not intended to love him; the reader knows I had wrought hard to extirpate from my soul the germs of love there detected; and now, at the first renewed view of him, they spontaneously revived, great and strong! He made me love him without looking at me." -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: Hala add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "Laws and principles are not for the times when there is no temptation: they are for such moments as this, when body and soul rise in mutiny against their rigour ... If at my convenience I might break them, what would be their worth?" -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: Hala add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "I am not an angel,' I asserted; 'and I will not be one till I die: I will be myself. Mr. Rochester, you must neither expect nor exact anything celestial of me - for you will not get it, any more than I shall get it of you: which I do not at all anticipate." -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: Hala add a quote by Quentin Crisp
item.description: "I am unable to believe in a God susceptible to prayer. I simply haven't the nerve to imagine a being, a force, a cause which keeps the planets revolving in their orbits, and then suddenly stops in order to give me a bicycle with three speeds." -- Quentin Crisp

item.title: Hala add a quote by Quentin Crisp
item.description: "If love means anything at all it means extending your hand to the unlovable." -- Quentin Crisp

item.title: Hala add a quote by Quentin Crisp
item.description: "Muddled syntax is the outward and audible sign of confused minds, and the misuse of grammar the result of illogical thinking." -- Quentin Crisp

item.title: Hala add a quote by Jean Genet
item.description: "First of all, don't mix your hairpins up with mine! You .... Oh! All right, mix your muck with mine. Mix it! Mix your rags with my tatters! Mix it all up. ..." -- Jean Genet

item.title: Hala add a quote by Jean Genet
item.description: "She was happy, and perfectly in line with the tradition of those women they used to call "ruined," "fallen," feckless, bitches in heat, ravished dolls, sweet sluts, instant princesses, hot numbers, great lays, succulent morsels, everybody's darlings . . . " -- Jean Genet

item.title: Hala add a quote by Jean Genet
item.description: "The rims of his eyelids were burning. A blow received straightens a man up and makes the body move forward, to return that blow, or a punch-to jump, to get a hard-on, to dance: to be alive. But a blow received may also cause you to bend over, to shake, to fall down, to die. When we see life, we call it beautiful. When we see death, we call it ugly. But it is more beautiful still to see oneself living at great speed, right up to the moment of death. Detectives, poets, domestic servants and priests rely on abjection. From it, they draw their power. It circulates in their veins. It nourishes them." -- Jean Genet

item.title: Hala add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "In spite of everything I loved you, and will go on loving you―on my knees, with my shoulders drawn back, showing my heels to the headsman and straining my goose neck―even then. And afterwards―perhaps most of all afterwards―I shall love you, and one day we shall have a real, all-embracing explanation, and then perhaps we shall somehow fit together, you and I, and turn ourselves in such a way that we form one pattern, and solve the puzzle: draw a line from point A to point B... without looking, or, without lifting the pencil... or in some other way... we shall connect the points, draw the line, and you and I shall form that unique design for which I yearn. If they do this kind of thing to me every morning, they will get me trained and I shall become quite wooden." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Hala add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "I think it is all a matter of love; the more you love a memory the stronger and stranger it becomes" -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Hala add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "Dear Jesus, do something." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Hala add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "Literature was not born the day when a boy crying "wolf, wolf" came running out of the Neanderthal valley with a big gray wolf at his heels; literature was born on the day when a boy came crying "wolf, wolf" and there was no wolf behind him." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Hala add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "Children of her type contrive the purest philosophies. Ada had worked out her own little system. Hardly a week had elapsed since Van’s arrival when he was found worthy of being initiated in her web of wisdom. An individual’s life consisted of certain classified things: "real things" which were unfrequent and priceless, simply "things" which formed the routine stuff of life; and "ghost things," also called "fogs," such as fever, toothache, dreadful disappointments, and death. Three or more things occurring at the same time formed a "tower," or, if they came in immediate succession, they made a "bridge." "Real towers" and "real bridges" were the joys of life, and when the towers came in a series, one experienced supreme rapture; it almost never happened, though. In some circumstances, in a certain light, a neutral "thing" might look or even actually become "real" or else, conversely, it might coagulate into a fetid "fog." When the joy and the joyless happened to be intermixed, simultaneously or along the ramp of duration, one was confronted with "ruined towers" and "broken bridges." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Hala add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "The sky was so heartless and dark, and her body, her head, and particularly those damned thirsty trousers, felt clogged with Oceanus Nox, n,o,x. At every slap and splash of cold wild salt, she heaved with anise-flavored nausea and there was an increasing number, okay, or numbness in her neck and arms. As she began losing track of herself, she thought it proper to inform a series of receding Lucettes -- telling them to pass it on and on in a trick-crystal regression -- that what death amounted to was only a more complete assortment of the infinite fractions of solitude." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Hala add a quote by Haruki Murakami
item.description: "What do you think? I'm not a starfish or a pepper tree. I'm a living, breathing human being. Of course I've been in love." -- Haruki Murakami

item.title: Hala add a quote by Haruki Murakami
item.description: "Don't feel sorry for yourself. Only assholes do that." -- Haruki Murakami

item.title: Hala add a quote by Haruki Murakami
item.description: "For a while" is a phrase whose length can't be measured.At least by the person who's waiting." -- Haruki Murakami

item.title: Hala add a quote by Haruki Murakami
item.description: "And you really will have to make it through that violent, metaphysical, symbolic storm. No matter how metaphysical or symbolic it might be, make no mistake about it: it will cut through flesh like a thousand razor blades. People will bleed there, and you will bleed too. Hot, red blood. You'll catch that blood in your hands, your own blood and the blood of others. And once the storm is over you won't remember how you made it through, how you managed to survive. You won't even be sure, in fact, whether the storm is really over. But one thing is certain. When you come out of the storm you won't be the same person who walked in. That's what this storm's all about." -- Haruki Murakami

item.title: Hala add a quote by Haruki Murakami
item.description: "A certain type of perfection can only be realized through a limitless accumulation of the imperfect." -- Haruki Murakami

item.title: Hala add a quote by Ted Hughes
item.description: "Applause is the beginning of abuse" -- Ted Hughes

item.title: Hala add a quote by Toni Morrison
item.description: "As you enter positions of trust and power, dream a little before you think." -- Toni Morrison

item.title: Hala add a quote by Toni Morrison
item.description: "There is a loneliness that can be rocked. Arms crossed, knees drawn up, holding, holding on, this motion, unlike a ship's, smooths and contains the rocker. It's an inside kind--wrapped tight like skin. Then there is the loneliness that roams. No rocking can hold it down. It is alive. On its own. A dry and spreading thing that makes the sound of one's own feet going seem to come from a far-off place." -- Toni Morrison

item.title: Hala add a quote by Toni Morrison
item.description: "A dream is just a nightmare with lipstick." -- Toni Morrison

item.title: Hala add a quote by Dorothy Parker
item.description: "They sicken of the calm who know the storm." -- Dorothy Parker

item.title: Hala add a quote by Dorothy Parker
item.description: "That would be a good thing for them to cut on my tombstone: Wherever she went, including here, it was against her better judgment." -- Dorothy Parker

item.title: Hala add a quote by Dorothy Parker
item.description: "Take me or leave me; or, as is the usual order of things, both." -- Dorothy Parker

item.title: Hala add a quote by Dorothy Parker
item.description: "Don't look at me in that tone of voice." -- Dorothy Parker

item.title: Hala add a quote by F. Scott Fitzgerald
item.description: "Strange children should smile at each other and say, "Let's play." -- F. Scott Fitzgerald

item.title: Hala add a quote by F. Scott Fitzgerald
item.description: "The kiss originated when the first male reptile licked the first female reptile, implying in a subtle way that she was as succulent as the small reptile he had for dinner the night before." -- F. Scott Fitzgerald
